SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES

No. 2

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

A word of explanation to the person answering this questionnaire

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experiences; others may prove impossible for you to answer, so don't worry about leaving blank spaces. Use extra sheets of paper if there is not sufficient space to answer the questions. Don't hesitate to give details, or describe particular events, if they help to answer the questions.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1914, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires

Saskatchewan Archives Questionnaire No. 1, entitled "Pioneer Diet: What Did Western Canadian Pioneers Eat?" is still being circulated. If you have not already answered this, and would be willing to do so, please put a check mark here (✓) and one will be sent to you.

Saskatchewan Archives questionnaires on other subjects will be prepared at a later date. Some of these are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer.

(✓) All questionnaires
(✓) Pioneer health conditions
(✓) Pioneer social life, sports and recreation
(✓) Pioneer housing
(✓) Pioneer education and churchwork
(✓) Pioneer farming experience

Preservation of Questionnaires

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives Board's Office at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent record of our Province. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

NOTE: Please print all proper names and place names in capital letters. If you are not sure the name is correct as you have given it, please say so. If you rather have someone else do the writing at your direction, this is quite acceptable.

1. Your full name: Robert James Rutherford
2. Your address: Fleming, Sask.
3. Date: December 14th, 1963
4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country): William Rutherford, Saskatchewan
5. What was your father's name and occupation?: William Rutherford, Saskatchewan
6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year): Oct 22nd, 1882
7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible.: Moffatt, Ontario / 1876 - 1882
8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not or you may use "I was a small child")
   "I was in my teens", etc.
9. What were your reasons for coming West?: To live with the family
10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Railroad or government information?):
    Through the "Manitoba newspapers"
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada? They thought we'd be killed by Indians or have to freeze or starve to death.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)? Family

13. What means of transportation did you use? She took the S.S. Polyanica to Quebec & from there by train to Fleming N.W.T.

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement etc.). She recorded some there on the papers.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan? She got off the train at Fleming N.W.T. & stayed at the farm of the friend already mentioned all of the winter of '82-3.

16. Where did you settle or take up land? My father homesteaded near here where I am today.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan. No other places.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How after you came? After my father was honorably discharged from the British army he was manager for the Bread making firm of James Inglis & Co Castle Street Belfast, Ireland.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada? They thought it was a good idea.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)? By family.

13. What means of transportation did you use? She took the SS for special train from here by train to Flinching N.W.T.

14. What incidents of the journey west do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement, etc.) Train at Flinching N.W.T., stayed at the farm of his friend already mentioned, all of the winter of 1872-3.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan? She got here.

16. Where did you settle or take up land? My father homesteaded right there where I am living.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan. No other places.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How after you came?

After my father was thoroughly discharged from the British army he was manager for the Bread making firm of Young & Co. at Portage Street Buffart, Ontario.
19. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home?

Maybe 10 years

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date and place of marriage.

I was married in 1918 to Guilla MacMills

21. Did anyone else come to Saskatchewan because of your recommending it as a place to settle?

No

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came West tell when they came and where they settled.

They all settled here

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to record?

I have written some of these things for the local newspaper

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (for business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.) How often? How far? By what means of travel?

Often
19. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old town?

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date and place of marriage.

21. Did anyone else come to Saskatchewan because of your recommendation it as a place to settle?

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came West, let them tell you what they felt about living there.

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to record? If so, describe it.

24. What was your favorite thing for the week?

Newspaper

25. Did you travel about much in the early years? (For business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.) How far? How often? How much? By what means of travel?
25. When was the first car used in the community?

26. If you owned a car before 1914, when did you buy it? What make?

27. Where was your trading center? How far from your home? (My father went to Brandon (60 miles) for ours.) 15 miles.

28. Did you continue to trade there? (Indicate any changes due to new towns appearing, better means of travel, etc.). For several years, then we changed to dealing.

29. How often did you shop in the early days? (My neighbors used to bring stuff for each other.)

30. When (if ever) did people in your district first start going to town regularly on Saturdays? Maybe 20 years.

31. When (if ever) did you first begin to buy through the mail order catalogues? What kind of articles did you buy in this way? Indicate also what fraction of your total purchases were by mail order and any changes in the proportion of purchases made by mail order since the pioneer period. 1900 I think mostly clothing. They are now about one third.

32. When did you first have a telephone and what company provided it? I can't remember exactly.

33. When you came to Saskatchewan the first time was it with the idea of staying permanently? Or did you make up your mind after trying it out? When did you make this decision? My father was going back after he had made his fortune (but he died in our years).

26. If you owned a car before 1914, when did you buy it? What make?

27. Where was your trading center? How far from your home?

28. Did you continue to trade there? If so, why?

29. How often did you shop in the early days?

30. When (if ever) did people in your district first start going to town regularly on Saturdays?

31. When (if ever) did you first begin to buy through the mail order catalogues? What kind of articles did you buy in this way? Include also what fraction of your total purchases were by mail order and any changes in the proportion of purchases made by mail order since the pioneer period.

32. When did you first have a telephone and what company provided it?

33. When you came to Saskatchewan the first time was it with the idea of staying permanently or did you make up your mind after trying it out?
34. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1914? What reasons did they have for moving?

A lot of people moved—many because of mortgage or lack of work. Some left because of the money—some people often because they couldn't take it.

35. Did many people move away during the 1930's? Did many return?

No one left then.

36. If you or some member of your family have held public office, or have been active in any organizations, mention it here, giving dates wherever possible.

My brother was the first teacher in our new school 1889. I am a past Grand Chancellor of the G.R. Knights of Pythias Regina 1934.

37. If you or any of your family or friends were "first" to have or do something in the district mention it here giving dates wherever possible. (Such as owning the first automobile, combine, organizing the first lodge, etc.).

38. How did the places in your community get their names? (School districts, Post Offices, villages, railway stations, creeks, hills, etc.). Try to give: (1) name and occupation of person suggesting place-name (2) origin and meaning of the name (3) date of its adoption (4) any changes in names since the first name was given—date and reason for change. Give facts of new name as above in (2), (3), (4).

My mother named the district Inglefield in honor of my father's old employer. She being the first woman in the district. The town of Glenning was named after the great benefactor of that name, Mr. James. So on.

McKeehan Bridge in honor of the original builder of that name.
36. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1914? What reasons did they have for moving?

A lot of people moved—a few because of hardship—lifestyle changes or it was more convenient to live elsewhere.

37. Did many people move away during the 1930s? Did many return?

No one left the parish after.

38. If you or some member of your family have held public offices, or have been active in any organizations, mention it here, giving dates wherever possible.

My father was the parish treasurer in our town. He served for years.

39. In the district mentioned above, did you or any of your family or friends own an automobile, combine, or organize the first lodge, etc.?

Yes, my father owned an automobile.

40. How did the places in your community get their names? (School districts, Post Offices, villages, railway stations, creeks, hills, etc.) Try to give: (1) date of its adoption; (2) reason for adopting place-name; (3) date of its adoption; (4) reason for adopting place-name.

My mother named the parish "Glenfield" in honor of her late husband. She lived there for many years after he passed.

"My name is 'Bridge' in honor of the original pioneer of this name."
